articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: This bulletin from "The Ephemeris" details upcoming events for the San Jose Astronomical Association, including a general meeting featuring Voyager-Saturn encounter footage and an October grase expedition. It also announces new policies for lending club telescopes, provides updates on recent professional comet discoveries and recoveries, and features a section of astronomy-related classified advertisements and local business news.

articles.title: Great Comets
articles.summary: The article discusses Comet Tebbutt (1861II), discovered by John Tebbutt on May 13, 1861, as a 4th magnitude object. It brightened significantly, with Sir John Herschel noting it as the brightest he had seen. Notably, on June 30, Earth passed through the comet's tail, causing a darkened sun and yellow sky, though no ill effects were reported as the coma was millions of miles away.

articles.title: Some Observations of the Perseid Meteor Shower
articles.summary: Don Machholz, his wife Laura, and Vickie O'Fallon observed the peak of the Perseid meteor shower on August 12 from Loma Prieta, reporting high hourly rates of 70-74 meteors. They differentiated between Perseid and background meteors, noting several bright events around magnitude -2.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: This article recounts a successful star party at Fremont Peak on August 1, 1981, highlighting the numerous telescopes and attendees, alongside an update on a new mercury-vapor light installation at the site, which park staff committed to turning off for observers. The author then details two observational techniques, the "blinking" and "prism" tricks, for locating faint planetary nebulae, concluding with descriptions of several specific planetary nebulae of interest.

articles.title: In June, I looked for the planetaries NGC 6578 and NGC 6620, in Sagittarius, and couldn't find either one. I was using the excellent AAVSO Variable Star Atlas, which plots stars to magnitude 9.5, so there was no ambiguity about identifying the field. I did a little research, and found that the AAVSO Atlas, the Skalnate Pleso (charts), the Skalnate Pleso Catalog (book), and Burnham's Celestial Handbook all agree exactly on the positions of these two objects, and are all wrong! I found different positions in Sulentic and Tifft's Revised New General Catalog and went back to the telescope with them. Sure enough, the planetaries were at the RNGC positions. NGC 6578 is about half a degree southeast of the erroneous position, and NGC 6620 is about a quarter degree east of the false location. That's clear in the net; country when one is sweeping for a small, faint object. (Both these planetaries are thirteenth to fourteenth magnitude and around a tenth of an arc-minute in diameter.) articles.summary: An amateur astronomer encountered significant errors in popular astronomical atlases and catalogs regarding the positions of planetary nebulae NGC 6578 and NGC 6620 in Sagittarius. After extensive research, the correct coordinates were found in Sulentic and Tifft's Revised New General Catalog, enabling successful observation. The author also briefly mentions the Egg Nebula and observations of galaxies in the Hercules Cluster.

articles.title: Who Owns Loma Prieta?
articles.summary: This article discusses the ongoing issue of obtaining permission to use Loma Prieta for astronomical activities, specifically for events like the Messier Marathon. The author investigated property ownership and contacted C.H.Y. of Sacramento, who, due to insurance liabilities, could not grant written permission despite finding the hobby "interesting and worthwhile." The author believes that as long as users remain on the road, there will be no issues, especially since local residents are supportive.

articles.title: Shuttle Schedule
articles.summary: The shuttle orbiter Columbia has been assembled with its fuel tank and boosters for its second flight, with the nine-day Shuttle Interface Test commencing on August 17. NASA is experiencing delays with the rollout to the launch pad, potentially pushing it back four or five days past August 26, which would likely impact the planned September 30 launch date for STS-2.

articles.title: Solar Mesosphere Explorer to Track Ozone Production
articles.summary: The Solar Mesosphere Explorer (SME) is scheduled for launch around September 15th from Vandenberg AFB. This 958-lb spacecraft will carry five instruments to monitor ozone, minor atmospheric instruments, temperature, water vapor, and incoming solar radiation. Its primary mission is to determine the role these factors play in ozone production within the mesosphere and overlapping upper atmosphere.

articles.title: Reusable Relics
articles.summary: NASA is retrieving 35 specialized fans from the backup Skylab space station housed at the Smithsonian Institute's National Air and Space Museum. This initiative aims to save over $500,000 by reusing existing spaceflight hardware for the shuttle and spacelab programs. New units would cost over $22,000 each due to their unique materials and spark-free brushless d.c. motors.

articles.title: NASA/RCA Twin Dynamics Explorer Spacecraft Put in Abnormal Orbit
articles.summary: On August 3, NASA and RCA's twin Dynamics Explorer spacecraft were placed into an abnormal orbit due to a short burn of the Delta 3913 booster's second stage following launch from Vandenberg AFB. Despite this initial anomaly, the Dynamics Explorer science mission is still anticipated to be completed successfully.

articles.title: Planned Shuttle Schedule
articles.summary: NASA has outlined its upcoming Space Shuttle launch schedule, with the third flight set for January 18, 1982. Subsequent launches are planned through May 1983, detailing flights 4 through 8, including dates in May, September, and December 1982, and March and May 1983.

articles.title: DETERMINING NAKED-EYE MAGNITUDE LIMIT USING THE "GREAT SQUARE OF PEGASUS"
articles.summary: Don Machholz describes a straightforward method to determine one's naked-eye magnitude limit by observing the "Great Square of Pegasus." The technique involves counting the number of stars visible within this prominent asterism and then using a provided table to correlate the observed star count with a corresponding limiting magnitude, thus giving a rough estimate of observational capability.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL WEEKEND
articles.summary: Bill Dellinges attended Dr. William Kaufmann's "Exploring the Universe" weekend workshop near Lake Tahoe, participating in stargazing sessions at an observatory housing a Celestron-22. Despite some participants being new to astronomy, the event fostered a rich learning environment, offering views of popular celestial objects through various telescopes and binoculars, alongside opportunities for camaraderie and meteor watching. Dellinges highly recommends the workshop for its educational value and the overall enjoyable experience of engaging with the night sky.

articles.title: SPACE TELESCOPE STATUS
articles.summary: NASA's Space Telescope primary mirror is nearing completion, undergoing its initial coating after two and a half years of precise shaping and polishing. Scheduled for an early 1985 launch, this 94-inch telescope is expected to significantly enhance astronomical observation, allowing views of stars 50 times fainter than currently possible with ground-based instruments.

articles.title: Dealing With Light Pollution
articles.summary: This satirical article offers unconventional and often humorous advice for combating light pollution, ranging from a dark-humored suggestion of using a shotgun on offending lights to more 'persuasive' tactics. It primarily illustrates a dialogue where an amateur astronomer tries to convince a truck stop owner to reduce excessive lighting by appealing to his financial, security, and patriotic concerns, rather than mentioning astronomy. The piece highlights the challenges of dark sky preservation with a strong dose of irony.

articles.title: Private Astronomy
articles.summary: The poem "Private Astronomy" describes the deeply personal and solitary experience of stargazing, emphasizing a sense of wildness, wonder, and intimate connection with the universe away from others. The author revels in imaginative contemplation of cosmic sounds, the perceived asymmetry of time, and a profound, private joy derived from witnessing the night sky. This cherished communion with the cosmos, a "fine little ache," is kept secret and tucked away as dawn approaches.

articles.title: SJAA Ephemeris
articles.summary: The "SJAA Ephemeris" is a monthly publication of the San Jose Astronomical Association, serving as a bulletin for its members. It provides contact information for the editor and club officers, alongside details regarding membership and bulletin subscription fees.
